e4: Although some investors might initially be confused by the change, it is ultimately more ethical to provide accurate financial information. This builds trust with all investors in the long run and mitigates legal risks associated with knowingly misleading financial reporting, even if the practice was previously accepted.
e5: An ethical reporting policy prioritizes transparency and accuracy. It avoids intentional misrepresentation or omission of material information, even if such practices are commonplace or deemed beneficial in the short term.  The policy should be clear, readily understandable by all stakeholders, and consistently applied to build trust and ensure fair treatment for all investors.
e6: Yes, I would ask management to develop a detailed communication plan for investors outlining the reasons behind the policy change, emphasizing the commitment to accurate and transparent reporting. I'd also inquire about potential mitigation strategies for any short-term market fluctuations following the announcement.
